text: (upbeat music)
(machinery clanging)
(keyboard tapping)
(machinery whizzing)

- We are one of the market
leaders in our segment,

and want to become the best
B2B eCommerce platform.
To grow fast,

we have to deliver the
best customer experience
on all channels
and we have to use the best technology
to respond very quickly
to our businesses' and customer needs.

- The initial aim was
to increase flexibility
and to speed up our development,
while also making systems scalable.

We've built our components
with infrastructure as code

which allows us to reuse
them across environments

and across our stacks, while
also developing them faster.
(upbeat music continues)

- Our first step was a
straight lift and shift

from on-premises at a
service provider to AWS.
Since then, we have broken up
our old monolithic architecture
by using more and more AWS components

for microservices,
containers, and data flows.
- Over the last three years running on AWS
we've achieved a lot.
The main thing being that we handle
and own entire stack ourselves.

We started with the obvious
infrastructure components,

like RDS for databases,
ALBs for load balancing
and CloudFront for static resources,
and also using ECS for running containers.

Since then, we've moved
a lot of functionality

out of our SAP hybris core
system into microservices.

And we are now using a lot more
cloud-native functionality,

including AWS Fargate for
running the containers

as well as services like S3,
Aurora, DynamoDB, and EFS.
We've built a new store front
with many new services for our customers,

including tailored
discounts and navigation,
which all run on microservices.

- We can continuously deploy
and test new functionality

on all environments with
no infrastructure headaches

and we can more easily attract
new engineering talents

who enjoy working in a
highly professional setup.

- Migration to AWS has
brought KAISER+KRAFT
a lot of benefits.

We've dramatically improved
performance and flexibility
by using microservices.

An example is that we've cut
the time for full price update
by a factor of 30,

from several days with a
lot of human interaction

down to just a few hours
fully autonomously.

We also use AWS Batch
with job orchestration
done by AWS Step Functions.

And we can run our
automated tests that way.

We've taken the time required
to run these automated tests

down from 85 minutes, all
the way to 25 minutes.

And the tests are running
a lot more stable now
than they have before.
(lively music)

- Our new operating model allows
us to both scale resources

and costs to our needs
without wasting staff time.

While spending on infrastructure
costs in absolute terms
may not be much lower,
we spend money in a more valuable way
to solve business problems much faster.
- From the operational point of view,

we can offer our team a
development and operating environment

that allows them to perform
at the top of their skills.

Using continuous integration
and continuous delivery

allows us DevOps to
solve issues more quickly
and have more time available to solve
and help our team with issues.

Our people work smarter
and better together
thanks to AWS.

- We now have the right
tools to keep improving

our customers' experience in
whatever channel they use.

The entire architecture
is laid out in a way
that works really well together

and means we can easily scale
every component independently
to achieve exactly what we want.
The real beauty of the system
is not that it reaches an endpoint,

but that it allows us
to continue to evolve

and develop in response to
what our customers want.
What's great about this

is as our business is
developing and growing,
the architecture can grow with us.
(lively music continues)
